[[File:Theodore Dietrich Garbade.jpg|thumb|Theodore Dietrich Garbade]] '''Theodore Dietrich Garbade''' (September 12, 1873 – January 26, 1961) was a merchant and [[bank]]er, he was President of the Union of Manufacturers of Cigars of [[Cuba]].
As a young man he moved from the German Village of Cigarmakers “''Zigarrenmacherdorf'' “Hastedt,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edition-temmen.de/blog/tag/hastedt/|title=Hastedt – DENN MAN TAU|website=www.edition-temmen.de|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> [[Bremen]] to Cuba where he worked as a leaf buyer for [[Hermann Dietrich Upmann]] and his [[Tobacco industry|Tobacco]] Company.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UJRBAQAAMAAJ&q=Teodore+Garbade+Cigar&dq=Teodore+Garbade+Cigar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUhJmW2czWAhWRKVAKHZcID5gQ6AEIKDAA|title=United States Tobacco Journal|date=1915|publisher=BMT Publications|language=en}}</ref> He was President of the Union of Manufacturers of Cigars of [[Cuba]], and joined [[H. Upmann|H.Upmann]] as an associate member and became their partner<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.es/books?id=2MozAQAAMAAJ&q=Theodor+Garbade&dq=Theodor+Garbade&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1tMPv18rWAhWRaVAKHdvNDdQQ6AEIPDAD|title=The London Banks and Kindred Companies and Firms ...|last=(bart.)|first=Sir Thomas Skinner|date=1916|publisher=T. Skinner & Company|language=en}}</ref> at the Bank: [[H. Upmann & Co.]] till 1917 when he moved to [[New York City|New York]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=G5JBAQAAMAAJ&q=teodoro+garbade&dq=teodoro+garbade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzNHptsrWAhUKYlAKHQoMC0YQ6AEIJjAA|title=United States Tobacco Journal|date=1914|publisher=BMT Publications|language=en}}</ref> He was Head of the [[Chamber of commerce|Chamber of Commerce]] in Cuba in 1917.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JkAwAQAAMAAJ&q=teodoro+garbade&dq=teodoro+garbade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzNHptsrWAhUKYlAKHQoMC0YQ6AEIODAD|title=Memoria que la Junta Directiva presentara a la asamblea general ordinaria|last=Cuba|first=Cámara de Comercio, Industria y Navegación de la Isla de|date=1917|publisher=Cámara|language=es}}</ref>
Theodore Garbade played a significant role in the settlement between Cuba and the [[United States]] after, [[Woodrow Wilson|President Wilson]] succeeded 1913 in passing the [[Revenue Act of 1913|Revenue Act,]] also known as the Tariff Act, or the Underwood Act. The Act established the lowest rates since the [[Walker Tariff]] of 1857. Most schedules were ''ad valorem'' basis, a percentage of the value of the item. This had a profound impact for the Cuban [[Tobacco industry|Tobacco Industry]] concerning their import to the States. As President of the Union of Manufacturers of Cigars of [[Cuba]] Garbade, aided by an appointed committee, laid this out to Cuban ´s President [[Mario García Menocal]] in January 1914, insisting upon an allowance of 50 per cent on their exports of cigars as an equivalent in Cuba’s next reciprocity treaty and urging a prompt solution of this matter so vital to the Cuban cigar industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forgottenbooks.com/en/readbook/TheCubaReview_10559666#106|title=The Cuba Review|website=www.forgottenbooks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref>
A German [[Citizenship|Citizen]] in the United States in 1916, he was considered [[prisoner of war]], and put under [[house arrest]] in his mansion in [[Mount Kisco, New York|Mount Kisko]], New York. In 1919 he moved to [[San Sebastián|San Sebastian]], [[Spain]] and in 1921 to [[Lucerne]], [[Switzerland]] where he applied for a Swiss passport. Owner of [[plantation]]s and other properties in Cuba, he lost a great part of his fortune by [[Confiscation]] in 1960 after the [[Cuban Revolution]]. He died only one year later. Garbade was married four times. Theodor jr, is son of his first spouse Graziella Aguirre del Monte who died in 1909. His second wife Aida Heydrich (1887 -1920),<ref>New York City Marriage licences,Index 1807-1995, Manhattan 2016</ref> daughter of [[Emilio Heydrich]], gave him two sons: [[Robert D. Garbade]] [[Filmmaking|(Filmmaker]] and first [[Camera operator|cameraman]] of the [[Schweizer Fernsehen|Swiss Television]]) and [[Bernhard Garbade|Bernhard R. Garbade]], director of “[[Zurich Insurance Group|Zurich]]” Insurance Group, [[Philanthropy|Philanthropist]] and [[Sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]] of {{Interlanguage link|Max Maag|de|Max Maag|WD=}} Church Organs. Theodore Garbade is buried with his last wife Hildegard von Ohlen (1903 -1962)<ref>England & Wales Citvil registration marriage index, 1916-2005,page no 1511, von Ohlen,Garbade</ref> at the [[Flims|Flims Waldhaus]] cemetery, Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bDcLAAAAYAAJ&q=teodoro+garbade&dq=teodoro+garbade&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzNHptsrWAhUKYlAKHQoMC0YQ6AEIKjAB|title=Historia de familias cubanas|last=Jaruco)|first=Francisco Xavier de Santa Cruz y Mallén (conde de San Juan de|date=1940|publisher=Editorial Hércules|isbn=9780897294089|language=es}}</ref>
== Literature == * Reginald Lloyd, Jose' Pla' Carceles: ''Twentieth Century Impressions of Cuba'',Editor: Lloyds Greater Britain publishing Company, Limited, 1913 * ''The Cuba Review and Bulletin, Editor:Munson Steamship Line, 1913'' * ''United States Tobacco Journa''l,Vol.83, BMT Publications, 1915 * Thomas Skinner: ''The London Banks and Kindred Companies and Firms'', Editor: T. Skinner & Company, 1916 * Martin Torodash: ''Woodrow Wilson and the Tarriff Question: The Importance of the Underwood Act in His Reform Program''.Editor: New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Science, 1966<ref>{{cite book|title=Woodrow Wilson and the Tarriff Question: The Importance of the Underwood Act in His Reform Program|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yO47ygAACAAJ&dq=underwood+act&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi34KyM7YTXAhXIwxQKHbWbDu4Q6AEIJjAA|publisher=New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Science|date=1966|accessdate=2017-10-22|language=en|first=Martin|last=Torodash}}</ref> * Alfredo Gómez Llorens: ''Instituciones y ciclo económico de la República de Cuba''. Palibrio, 2014 * Noel Maurer: ''The Empire Trap: The Rise and Fall of U.S. Intervention to Protect American'' ,Editor: Princeton University Press,2013, {{ISBN|978-0-691-15582-1}}

Basin|publisher=UNH / GRDC|accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref> | discharge1_min = {{convert|3120|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_avg = {{convert|19600|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_max = {{convert|112000|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} <!---------------------- BASIN FEATURES --> | source1 = [[Ka-Hem|Mungaragiyn-Gol]] | source1_location = ridge [[Dod-Taygasyn-Noor]], [[Mongolia]] | source1_coordinates= {{coord|50|43|46|N|98|39|49|E|display=inline}} | source1_elevation = {{convert|3351|m|abbr=on}} | mouth = [[Yenisei Gulf]] | mouth_location = [[Arctic ocean]], [[Russia]] | mouth_coordinates = | mouth_elevation = | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|2580000|km2|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = | tributaries_right = [[Angara River|Angara]], [[Lower Tunguska]], [[Stony Tunguska River]] | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }}
The '''Yenisei''' ({{lang-ru|Енисе́й}}, ''Jeniséj''; {{lang-mn|Енисей мөрөн}}, ''Yenisei mörön''; [[Buryat language|Buryat]]: Горлог мүрэн, ''Gorlog müren''; [[Tuvan language|Tyvan]]: Улуг-Хем, ''Uluğ-Hem''; [[Khakas language|Khakas]]: Ким суг, ''Kim sug'')<ref>A.Ochir. "History of the Mongol Oirats" 1993</ref> also Romanised '''Yenisey''', '''Enisei''', '''Jenisej''',<ref name=Hammond>{{cite encyclopedia | title = Yenisei River | author = | encyclopedia = Hammond Quick & Easy Notebook Reference Atlas & Webster Dictionary | publisher = Hammond|isbn= 0843709227 | date = | page = 31}}</ref> is the largest [[river]] system flowing to the [[Arctic Ocean]]. It is the central of the three great [[Siberia]]n rivers that flow into the Arctic Ocean (the other two being the [[Ob River|Ob]] and the [[Lena River|Lena]]). Rising in [[Mongolia]], it follows a northerly course to the [[Yenisei Gulf]] in the [[Kara Sea]], draining a large part of central Siberia, the longest stream following the Yenisei-[[Angara]]-[[Selenga]]-[[Ider River|Ider]] river system.
The maximum depth of the Yenisei is {{convert|80|ft|m|order=flip}} and the average depth is {{convert|45|ft|m|order=flip}}. The depth of river outflow is {{convert|106|ft|m|order=flip}} and inflow is {{convert|101|ft|m|order=flip}}.{{clarify|date=August 2015}}
==Course of the river== [[File:Слияние рек Енисей.jpg|thumb|260px|The confluence of the rivers Kaa-Khem and Piy-Khem from the height of bird flight]] The river flows through [[Tuva]], [[Khakassia]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/yenisei-river-siberia-hydroplant/|title=Yenisei River: Siberia’s blessing and curse|date=11 June 2010|publisher=RT|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref> and the city of [[Krasnoyarsk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/infocus/2013/08/a-year-on-the-yenisei-river/100580/|title=A Year on the Yenisei River|last=Alan Taylor|date=23 August 2013|publisher=[[The Atlantic]]|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref>
Its tributaries include the [[Angara River|Angara]], [[Nizhnyaya Tunguska River|Nizhnyaya Tunguska]], [[Podkamennaya Tunguska River|Podkamennaya Tunguska]] and [[Tuba River|Tuba]] rivers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eoearth.org/view/article/175644/|title=Yenisei River|last=C Michael Hogan|date=13 May 2012|publisher=[[Encyclopedia of Earth]]|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
==Lake Baikal== {{main|Lake Baikal}} The {{convert|320|km|mi|adj=on}}, partly navigable [[Upper Angara River]] feeds into the northern end of [[Lake Baikal]] from the [[Buryat Republic]] but the largest inflow is from the [[Selenga]] which forms a delta on the southeastern side. {{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
[[Image:Bank of Yenisei River.jpg|thumb|right|260px|The river as seen from the [[trans-Siberian railway]] near [[Krasnoyarsk]]]]
==Flora and fauna== The Yenisei River [[Drainage basin|basin]] (excluding Lake Baikal and lakes of the [[Khantayka River]] headwaters) is home to 55 native fish species, including two [[Endemism|endemics]]: ''[[Gobio sibiricus]]'' (a [[Gobioninae|gobionine]] [[cyprinid]]) and ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Thymallus nigrescens|es}}'' (a [[Thymallus|grayling]]).<ref name=FEOW>Freshwater Ecoregions of the World (2008). ''[http://www.feow.org/ecoregions/details/yenisei Yenisei.]'' Retrieved 16 July 2014.</ref> The grayling is restricted to [[Khövsgöl Nuur]] and its tributaries.<ref name=FEOW/> Most fish found in the Yenisei River basin are relatively widespread Euro-[[Siberia]]n or Siberian species, such as [[northern pike]] (''Esox lucius''), [[common roach]] (''Rutilus rutilus''), [[common dace]] (''Leuciscus leuciscus''), [[Siberian sculpin]] (''Cottus poecilopus''), [[European perch]] (''Perca fluviatilis'') and [[Prussian carp]] (''Carassius gibelio''). The basin is also home to many [[salmonids]] (trout, [[Freshwater whitefish|whitefish]], [[Salvelinus|charr]], graylings, [[taimen]] and relatives) and the [[Siberian sturgeon]] (''Acipenser baerii'').<ref name=FEOW/>
The Yenisei River valley is habitat for numerous flora and fauna, with [[Siberian pine]] and [[Siberian larch]] being notable tree species. In [[prehistoric]] times [[Scots pine]], ''Pinus sylvestris'', was abundant in the Yenisei River valley circa 6000 [[Anno Domini|BC]].<ref>Stein, Ruediger et al. 2003. ''Siberian river run-off in the Kara Sea'', Proceedings in Marine Sciences, Elsevier, Amsterdam, 488 pages</ref> There are also numerous bird species present in the watershed, including, for example, the [[hooded crow]], ''Corvus cornix''.<ref>C. Michael Hogan. 2009. [http://www.globaltwitcher.com/artspec_information.asp?thingid=26307 ''Hooded Crow: Corvus cornix'', GlobalTwitcher.com, ed, N. Stromberg]</ref>
===Taimyr reindeer herd=== The Taimyr [[reindeer]] herd, a migrating tundra reindeer (''R.t. sibiricus''), the largest reindeer herd in the world,<ref name=NOAA2013>{{Cite journal|title=Migratory Tundra Rangifer |first1=D.E. |last1=Russell|first2=A. |last2=Gunn|institution=NOAA Arctic Research Program|date=20 November 2013 }}</ref><ref name=Kolpashikov>{{cite journal|last1=Kolpashikov|first1=L.|first2=V. |last2=Makhailov|first3=D. |last3=Russell|date=2014|title=The role of harvest, predators and socio-political environment in the dynamics of the Taimyr wild reindeer herd with some lessons for North America|journal=Ecology and Society}}</ref> migrated to winter grazing ranges along the Yenisei River.<ref name="Baskin_1986">{{citation |title=Differences in the ecology and behaviour of reindeer populations in the USSR |first=Leonid M. |last=Baskin |url=http://septentrio.uit.no/index.php/rangifer/article/viewFile/667/634 |accessdate=7 January 2015 |journal=Rangifer |series=Special Issue |number=1 |year=1986 |pages=333–340 }}</ref>{{rp|336}}
==Navigation== [[File:Inclined plane at Krasnoyarsk, on the Yenisie River.jpg|thumb|[[canal inclined plane|Inclined plane]] at [[Krasnoyarsk Dam]]]] River steamers first came to the Yenesei River in 1864 and were brought in from Holland and England across the icy Kara Sea. One was the SS Nikolai. The SS Thames attempted to explore the river, overwintered in 1876, but was damaged in the ice and eventually wrecked in the river. Success came with the steamers Frazer, Express in 1878, and the next year, Moscow hauling supplies in and wheat out. The Dalman reached Yeneisisk in 1881.
Imperial Russia placed river steamers on the massive river in an attempt to free up communication with land-locked Siberia. One boat was the SS St. Nicholas which took the future Tsar Nicholas II on his voyage to Siberia, and later conveyed Vladimir Lenin to prison.
Engineers attempted to place river steamers on regular service on the river during the building of the Trans-Siberian Railway. The boats were needed to bring in the rails, engines and supplies. Captain Joseph Wiggins sailed the Orestes with rail and parted out river steamers in 1893. However, the sea and river route proved very difficult with several ships lost at sea and on the river. Both the Ob and Yenisei mouths feed into very long inlets, several hundred miles in length, which are shallow, ice bound and prone to high winds and thus treacherous for navigation. After the completion of the railway, river traffic reduced only to local service as the Arctic route and long river proved much too indirect a route.
The first recreation team to navigate the Yenisei's entire length, including its violent upper [[tributary]] in Mongolia, was an Australian-Canadian effort completed in September 2001. [[Ben Kozel]], Tim Cope, [[Colin Angus (explorer)|Colin Angus]] and Remy Quinter were on this team. Both Kozel and Angus wrote books detailing this expedition,<ref>Five Months in a Leaky Boat: A River Journey Through Siberia, Kozel, 2003, Pan Macmillan</ref> and a documentary was produced for National Geographic Television.
A [[canal inclined plane]] was built on the river in 1985 at the [[Krasnoyarsk Dam]].<ref name=ShipliftsPianc1989> {{cite book | isbn = 978-2-87223-006-8 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=hv48DrHv_l4C&dq=%22Ship+lifts%22+China | title = Ship lifts: report of a Study Commission within the framework of Permanent .. | publisher = [[PIANC]] | year = 1989 | accessdate = 2011-12-14 | author = Permanent International Association of Navigation Congresses. }} </ref>
==History== Nomadic tribes such as the [[Ket people]] and the [[Yugh people]] have lived along the banks of the Yenisei river since ancient times, and this region is the location of the [[Yeniseian languages|Yeniseian language family]]. The Ket, numbering about 1000, are the only survivors today of those who originally lived throughout central southern Siberia near the river banks. Their extinct relatives included the Kotts, Assans, Arins, Baikots, and Pumpokols who lived further upriver to the south. The modern Ket lived in the eastern middle areas of the river before being assimilated politically into Russia during the 17th through 19th centuries.<ref>{{cite web |last=Vajda |first=Edward G. |url=http://pandora.cii.wwu.edu/vajda/ea210/ket.htm |title=The Ket and Other Yeniseian Peoples |publisher= |accessdate=2006-10-27 }}</ref>
Wheat from the Yenisei was sold by Muslims and Uighurs during inadequate harvests to Bukhara and Soghd during the [[Tahirid]] era.<ref name="Blanchard2001">{{cite book|author=Ian Blanchard|title=Mining, Metallurgy and Minting in the Middle Ages: Asiatic supremacy, 425-1125|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zo2UVs_Sr68C&pg=PA271#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2001|publisher=Franz Steiner Verlag|isbn=978-3-515-07958-7|pages=271–272}}</ref>
Russians first reached the upper Yenisei in 1605, travelling from the Ob River, up the [[Ket River]], portaging and then down the Yenisei as far as the [[Sym River]].<ref name=Fisher1943>{{cite book | last = Fisher | first = Raymond Henry | title = The Russian Fur Trade, 1550-1700 | publisher = University of California Press | year = 1943 | location = | page = }}</ref>
During [[World War II]], [[Nazi Germany]] and the [[Japanese Empire]] agreed to divide Asia along a line that followed the Yenisei River to the border of China, and then along the border of China and the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>[[Gerhard Weinberg|Weinberg, Gerhard L]]. ''Visions of Victory: The Hopes of Eight World War II Leaders'' Cambridge, England, United Kingdom:2005--Cambridge University Press [http://assets.cambridge.org/97805218/52548/frontmatter/9780521852548_frontmatter.pdf]</ref>
==Pollution== Studies have shown that the Yenisei suffers from contamination caused by radioactive discharges from a factory that produced bomb-grade [[plutonium]] in the secret city of Krasnoyarsk-26, now known as [[Zheleznogorsk, Krasnoyarsk Krai|Zheleznogorsk]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/coldwar/siberiaa.htm|title=Wastes of War: Radioactivity Threatens a Mighty River|last=David Hoffman|date=17 August 1998|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
== Gallery == <center> <gallery> Image:Most 777, the bridge over the Yenisei in Krasnoyarsk, Russia, view from the left bank.jpg |The bridge over the Yenisei in Krasnoyarsk, Russia, viewed from the left bank. Image:Vantovyjj most, the bridge in Krasnoyarsk, Russia, view from the left bank.jpg|Vinogradovsky most, the bridge in Krasnoyarsk, Russia, viewed from the left bank File:Yenisei Ob Kara Sea.jpg|The Yenisei (left) and the Ob flow into Kara Sea. </gallery> </center>
